nodes.bodyText: Please extract this sleep time to a constant. Any thoughts on if it needs to be configurable?

It's a fairly limited use case (broker hostname is not resolvable at startup) so I went for a simpler single option configuration, rather than two options (number of times to retry + delay between retries).
I'm not sure that extracting it into a constant actually helps anything here.
In SmallRye, the wait between the retry is 30s. https://smallrye.io/smallrye-reactive-messaging/smallrye-reactive-messaging/2/kafka/kafka.html I think the default should be 30s instead of 0.

I disagree.
We can't tell the difference between a failure caused by the hostname not being resolvable and a failure caused by bad configuration.
If the user has configured the application wrongly, we want to app to fail to start as soon as possible, not pointlessly retry for 30s.
As far as we've seen so far, having the broker hostname not be resolvable is the only failure that Kafka treats this way, in most cases network failures are already retried automatically by the kafka client.

No-one should have to use this unless they're deploying in an environment where the kafka broker and the app are being brought up at the same time. (e.g. during a kubernetes deployment in a test environment)
Can we sync up with SmallRye for the retry-max-wait, retry-attempts?

I'm not sure what the point of those options are in smallrye, they don't seem to be the same as this one.
They talk about retrying the connection if it goes down, which is not what this change is doing.

I named the property creation.retry.seconds to emphasise that it's only the creation of the kafka client which is retried.
Once we have set up the kafka client, we leave it to do any retries itself.
Change could not be created to cannot be created or to was not created
Change the second "set up" to "setup" because it is a noun. Thus, change to: was set up for an incoming reactive messaging channel but the setup will be retried.
Per QA ID review, provide a couple of possible or likely errors that might have occurred to cause this error. The explanation should have more information than just a restating of the error message.
Also, avoid future tense if possible. You can achieve this by stating "when X, the setup is retried." instead of "the setup will be retried."

provide a couple of possible or likely errors that might have occurred to cause this error

I think I can do this. We're calling a third party API and it's throwing an exception. We don't know all the reasons that this error can occur but we can make a guess at what it might be.
The most important part of this message is informing the user that the error occurred during channel setup and which channel it occurred for. The error message included as placeholder {1} is the exception thrown by the API which hopefully says what's gone wrong.

avoid future tense if possible. You can achieve this by stating "when X, the setup is retried." instead of "the setup will be retried."

Hmm, we emit this message after catching an exception from a third-party API. We wait for a short period and then retry.
I guess I could say "the setup is being retried", even though we're actually going to wait a second or so before we actually retry it? Otherwise I'm not sure how to avoid using the future tense here.
@jantley-ibm I've made these changes, could you take a look at the latest commit on this PR? Thanks.
Change  set up to setup because it is a noun: the connector setup.

There's been additional ID QA review on this PR. For CWMRX1007E.explanation, we need to not say "An error ... occurred". The reviewer suggests that if there are multiple possible errors that could have occurred, we should provide a couple of the likely possible ones.
Per QA ID review, provide a couple of possible or likely errors that might have occurred to cause this error.

change "This may be" to "This might be"
("may" can indicate permission being granted, which can confuse translators)
